Yes. Updated the description.
Update the change.
Add support for task level key value pair get/put

The remove function will not supported in this patch. Since it will get the map from getSimpleFields,  remove the key, then reset the simple fields back. I dont think it worth of doing that way, since original property store does not support remove function.

We can monitor the usage of this content store. If user prefer to have the remove function. We shall add it from property store layer.
this is awesome Greg, can you please create a separate PR for FULL_AUTO bug. I will review the changes tonight.
@lei-xia can you also review this change. Subbu had a test case https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HELIX-631. Will be good to see if this change fixes that as well.

@kishoreg Sorry I should have been more clear - the FULL_AUTO bug was a problem in which the UI wouldn't show the table containing partition / ideal state / external view, as there is no state map information in a FULL_AUTO resource's ideal state. This doesn't touch the FULL_AUTO logic in `helix-core`
Ah here is the JIRA https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HELIX-627
Got it. Will review this. Are you guys using 0.6.x or 0.7.x
0.6.x because the beta label was a hard sell ðŸ˜„
LGTM
this is great work Lei. Can you please paste the final mapping generated by default strategy v/s crush method. Also when would one chose one over the other.
lgtm

Hi, Kishore.  I am working on a wiki/doc to introduce new topology aware rebalance strategy with some of experimental results showing stats of distribution of partitions and movements during rebalacing.  Will publish it once it is ready.
Yes, the tests passed.
Can you rebase to branch head?  There is merge conflict.
Rebased now. Thanks for reminder!

This should fix it. One scenario, where this will result in undesirable output is when the entire cluster is restarted.

Let's day P was on NODE_0 and NODE_1, we paused the controller, restarted all nodes and unpaused controller. It's desirable to put P on the same nodes (NODE_0, NODE_1), but since we remove it from the map, it might reassign it to another node and this will cause a lot of reshuffling.

Another alternative is to keep the current code but during sorting use the state priority followed by node names. With this change  currentMapping: `{P: {NODE_0: OFFLINE, NODE_1: ONLINE}}` after sorting should result in `[NODE_1, NODE_0]` and hence no movement.

@kishoreg that makes sense. For the node sort order, you're thinking
- sum of (state priority) for partitions on node
- node name

?
@kishoreg see #59 for a version of the sorting strategy

kishore g  on dev@helix.apache.org replies:
Yes. Thanks will review 59.

Maybe we should keep the partition count map in place.I am thinking about the case where new nodes get added, will the new change stop redistributing partitions.

A simple test case to try is 

2 nodes (n1,n2) with 6 partitions 
add a node(n3) 

 we should see one partition from n1,n2 move to n3. We already have that test case.

I think this strategy accounts for partition count and priority:
- it assigns each state a "score", which is just a reverse numbering of the priority-ordered state list
- it ranks nodes according to the sum of the state scores of the partitions on the node

I modified my test code to your 2/6 scenario, and it worked as expected:

```
Setting up cluster THE_CLUSTER
Starting CONTROLLER
Starting NODE_0
Starting NODE_1
Adding resource R
Rebalancing resource R
Transition: NODE_0 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_0
Transition: NODE_1 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_3
Transition: NODE_1 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_5
Transition: NODE_1 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_1
Transition: NODE_0 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_4
Transition: NODE_0 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_2
Cluster state after setup:
                NODE_0  NODE_1
        R_0     ONLINE  null
        R_1     null    ONLINE
        R_2     ONLINE  null
        R_3     null    ONLINE
        R_4     ONLINE  null
        R_5     null    ONLINE
------------------------------------------------------------
Starting NODE_2
Transition: NODE_0 ONLINE to OFFLINE for R_2
Transition: NODE_1 ONLINE to OFFLINE for R_5
Transition: NODE_0 OFFLINE to DROPPED for R_2
Transition: NODE_1 OFFLINE to DROPPED for R_5
Transition: NODE_2 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_5
Transition: NODE_2 OFFLINE to ONLINE for R_2
Cluster state after starting third node:
                NODE_0  NODE_1  NODE_2
        R_0     ONLINE  null    null
        R_1     null    ONLINE  null
        R_2     null    null    ONLINE
        R_3     null    ONLINE  null
        R_4     ONLINE  null    null
        R_5     null    null    ONLINE
------------------------------------------------------------
```

I can gist the test code if helpful.

You mentioned 

> We already have that test case.

How do you run the test cases? I've noticed the `build` script has them disabled, and a simple `mvn clean install` fails.

LGTM. @lei-xia can you also take a look at this. 

Regarding test case, standard mvn command to run a specific test should work. mvn clean install should work. What is the failure you are seeing? maybe we should discuss that on mailing list

@kishoreg confirmed I can run individual tests with e.g. `mvn clean test -Dtest=TestAutoRebalance -DfailIfNoTests=false`. The full `helix-core` test suite hits OOM errors on my machine, but that may be a local config issue.

@lei-xia can we get this into the ~~0.6.6 release~~? Oops, just noticed 0.6.6 on search.maven.org. 0.6.7?

@mkscrg  we already generated the 0.6.6 release,  will include this fix into our next release.  We will have more frequent releases from now on,  and next release is expected to be out in another 1 month or so.  If you really need this to be included in our official release and can not wait another month, please let us know and we can discuss internally to see whether we can build a hot release for you.
@lei-xia OK sounds good. Will keep in touch :+1:
Looks good to me.  Could you please include a test?
Could you please also rebase to the HEAD of the branch?  Thanks!

(Just FYI: github allows a squash-and-merge option that lets the reviewer merge the whole patch as a single commit - in case you want to use that flow in the future).
Thanks, I will merge your change.

Updated.

Sure. Just updated the commit and pull request.
Could you rebase against the current head?
Rebased now.

I think it's a good idea to have one shared thread pool. Since we create one callback per helix entity type (idealstate, external view), I thought this is not a big overhead.  The only exception is the current state property key which will spawn one thread per participant.

Looks good to me! I will do the following things for corresponding change:
1. Will add a test for this.
2. Will provide an API in HelixManager for enabling batch message and support cluster/resource level batch message enabling.

kishore g  on dev@helix.apache.org replies:
+1 on adding an api to enable/disable this at a cluster level.

Xue Junkai  on dev@helix.apache.org replies:
Sure! Will add that.
Any update on this PR. I think we are seeing similar issues in one of our projects
where do you want to use this?

For ZkClient, we have public APIs like:

  public void asyncCreate(final String path, Object datat, final CreateMode mode,
      final CreateCallbackHandler cb)

When user would like to use these async methods, they have to instantiate CallbackHandler class that hidden in ZkAsyncCallbacks.

Rebased against the latest apache/master

I think this commit will be dangerous as it changes the behavior from what Helix performed now. Our current users are relying on original behavior.

In addition, if the session reestablished, Helix lose the track of partition state in the participant. Simply carrying over the previous state is not a good idea. It is better not to make change happen unless there is a very strong reason to make this happen.

Thx for the comment. I create the pull request because the original bebavior confuses me when I write this part in go-helix and I cannot find issues section in this repo. I will stick with the original behavior in go then

Is controller code depending on the Routing table code by any chance? I saw RouterCache, could not figure out if thats used in controller or specator?

--  No, RouterCache depends on the BasicClusterCache which is in the  org.apache.helix.commons module, which the controller's ClusterDataCache also depends on.
Already merged. thanks!
Thanks!
Could you rebase to HEAD?
Please rebase to HEAD
Can you please rebase to the HEAD.
Please resolve the conflict
With this incremented id, you can not tell which thread runs which task either, right?

@lei-xia : Thanks for the feedback. It is possible. If the thread pool size is 40, there should be threads named from TaskStateModelFactory-task_thread-0 to ... 39. In the logs it should print either one of them as the thread id. This could be useful when we analyze thread dumps or to analyze the thread utilization of the participant.

@DImuthuUpe do you know how scheduled thread pool is managing threads internally? Is it always having a fixed number of 40 thread or its creating / deleting thread when needed but 40 is just an upper bound?

@zhan849 In the code, we are setting the core pool size as 40. Java doc says "corePoolSize - the number of threads to keep in the pool, even if they are idle, unless allowCoreThreadTimeOut is set". So it is a fixed number of threads. 

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.html#ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor(int,%20java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionHandler)
Could you please rebase to the current HEAD of master branch?  Thanks
